step_by_step.explanation: International trade is the exchange of goods and services across countries.

problems.final_answer: International trade: exchange of goods and services between countries.

step_by_step.explanation: A country has an absolute advantage if it can produce more of a good with the same resources than another country.

problems.final_answer: Absolute advantage: produce more with same resources.

step_by_step.explanation: A country has a comparative advantage if it can produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another country.

problems.final_answer: Comparative advantage: lower opportunity cost of production.

problems.problem: Explain why countries specialize according to comparative advantage.

step_by_step.explanation: Specialization allows countries to produce efficiently and trade to consume beyond their production possibilities frontier (PPF).

problems.final_answer: Specialization increases efficiency and allows consumption beyond PPF.

problems.problem: Explain the effect of tariffs on domestic consumers and producers.

step_by_step.explanation: Tariffs increase import prices, reducing consumer surplus.
Domestic producers benefit from reduced foreign competition, increasing producer surplus.

problems.final_answer: Tariffs: consumers lose, domestic producers gain.

problems.problem: Explain the effect of quotas on trade.

step_by_step.explanation: Quotas limit the quantity of imports, raising domestic prices, reducing consumer surplus, and increasing producer surplus.

problems.final_answer: Quotas: limit imports, raise prices, consumers lose, producers gain.

step_by_step.explanation: Trade protectionism involves government policies such as tariffs, quotas, and subsidies to protect domestic industries from foreign competition.

problems.final_answer: Trade protectionism: policies to shield domestic firms from foreign competition.

problems.problem: Explain how a country benefits from free trade.

step_by_step.explanation: Free trade allows countries to specialize according to comparative advantage, lowering costs, increasing efficiency, and improving total welfare.

problems.final_answer: Free trade: specialization, lower costs, higher total welfare.

problems.problem: Explain how exchange rates affect international trade.

step_by_step.explanation: A stronger domestic currency makes imports cheaper and exports more expensive, reducing export demand. A weaker domestic currency does the opposite.

problems.final_answer: Exchange rates: stronger currency → cheaper imports, fewer exports; weaker currency → cheaper exports, costlier imports.

problems.problem: A country can produce either 10 cars or 50 computers per day. Another country can produce 6 cars or 30 computers per day. Which country has comparative advantage in cars and computers?

step_by_step.explanation: Country A: 1 car = 5 computers (50/10), 1 computer = 0.2 cars (10/50)
Country B: 1 car = 5 computers (30/6), 1 computer = 0.2 cars (6/30)
Both countries have the same opportunity costs; no comparative advantage exists in this simplified example.

problems.final_answer: No comparative advantage; opportunity costs identical.
